raw_answer:
The document provides the following information regarding patient 'AII-11' from family 'Family A' and the mutation:

1.  **Identification of the Mutation:** The abstract states: "The p.D620N mutation was detected in 3 patients with autosomal dominant PD... None of the other reported variants of VPS35 were detected." Page 3, Figure 1A shows the pedigree for Family A, and patient II-11 (AII-11) is marked as affected and analyzed. The text on page 3 mentions "Patients carrying the p.D620N mutation did not have any other variants in all exons of VPS35," indicating p.D620N is the relevant mutation.

2.  **Genotype of the Mutation:** The "Results" section on page 2 states: "We detected the heterozygous missense p.D620N mutation in 3 unrelated patients with ADPD..." Patient AII-11 is one of these patients with ADPD from Family A.

3.  **Nucleotide Change:** The "Genetic Analysis" section on page 2 refers to the mutation as "c.1858G>A (p.D620N)". The "Discussion" on page 4 also refers to "the substitution of VPS35 c.1858G>A (p.D620N)".

Based on this information, the "first mutation" (which is the only VPS35 mutation detected in this patient according to the text) is p.D620N (c.1858G>A), and the genotype of patient AII-11 for this mutation is heterozygous.

Therefore, the genotype of the first mutation for patient 'AII-11' is heterozygous p.D620N (or heterozygous c.1858G>A). The document most directly states it as "heterozygous missense p.D620N mutation".

Heterozygous p.D620N
question: Regarding patient 'AII-11' from family 'Family A': What is the genotype of the first mutation?
